description:
Clostridium homopropionicum is an anaerobic, Gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium that belongs to the genus Clostridium. It is known for its ability to produce propionate as the primary end-product of its metabolism.

The cells of C. homopropionicum are typically rod-shaped and can form terminal spores. The bacterium is capable of growth in a wide range of temperatures, typically between 20°C and 40°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 30°C.

C. homopropionicum is capable of fermenting a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and lactate, to produce propionate as the main metabolic end-product. This metabolic capability makes it an important player in the anaerobic degradation of organic matter, particularly in environments such as sediments, anaerobic digesters, and the gastrointestinal tracts of various animals.

The presence of C. homopropionicum has been reported in various natural and engineered environments, and it is considered a member of the normal gut microbiota in some animals. Its role in the production of propionate and its potential interactions with other microorganisms in these environments are subjects of ongoing research.
